  physical_appearance: This stoneware pestle has a long neck
 that has been incised with a spiraling line. The neck is covered with an olive-green glaze.  It has a globular body
 that is unglazed and smooth at the bottom. The neck of the vessel is hollow. The pestle is slightly scratched with some black marks on its body.

  subject_terms_1: kitchenware ceramics (object genre)

 1115-1234 Kitchen utensils Ceramics

  subject_terms_3: Ceramics

  sgcool_label_text: The long neck of this vessel is incised with a spiralling line and covered with an olive-green glaze. In contrast
 its globular body is unglazed and smooth on the bottom
 which indicates the use of this stoneware as a pestle. The hollow neck of the vessel could also have been used to contain liquids. This allowed the user of the pestle to add small amounts of water
 wine or other liquids to the herbs or other substances that he/she was grinding.\r\nStone pestles and mortars have been used to prepare food and medicines in China since the Neolithic period (around 8
000 BC - 2
000 BC). Over time
 wooden
 ceramic and metallic pestles were also made and used in China. This pestle is a rare find as very few Chinese ceramic examples have survived from the pre-Qing period. \r\n

metadata.physical_appearance: This stoneware pestle has a long neck, that has been incised with a spiraling line. The neck is covered with an olive-green glaze.  It has a globular body, that is unglazed and smooth at the bottom. The neck of the vessel is hollow. The pestle is slightly scratched with some black marks on its body.
metadata.subject_terms_2: Pestles China History Jin dynasty, 1115-1234 Kitchen utensils Ceramics
metadata.sgcool_label_text:
The long neck of this vessel is incised with a spiralling line and covered with an olive-green glaze. In contrast, its globular body is unglazed and smooth on the bottom, which indicates the use of this stoneware as a pestle. The hollow neck of the vessel could also have been used to contain liquids. This allowed the user of the pestle to add small amounts of water, wine or other liquids to the herbs or other substances that he/she was grinding.
Stone pestles and mortars have been used to prepare food and medicines in China since the Neolithic period (around 8,000 BC - 2,000 BC). Over time, wooden, ceramic and metallic pestles were also made and used in China. This pestle is a rare find as very few Chinese ceramic examples have survived from the pre-Qing period.
